sub_topic: Finding the height of objects using trigonometry
message_1: A student standing 20 meters away from a tall building looks up at the top of the building at an angle of elevation of 45 degrees. Find the height of the building (round to the nearest meter) using trigonometry.
message_2:
To find the height of the building, we can use the tangent function in trigonometry. The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the side adjacent to the angle.

In this case, the angle of elevation is 45 degrees, the side adjacent to the angle is the distance from the student to the building (20 meters), and the side opposite the angle is the height of the building (which we want to find).

We can set up the equation:

tan(45Â°) = height / 20 meters

Since the tangent of 45 degrees is 1:

1 = height / 20 meters

Now, we can solve for the height:

height = 20 meters * 1

height = 20 meters

So, the height of the building is approximately 20 meters.
